Let $A=\{n_1<n_2<\cdots\}$ be an infinite sequence of integers, and let $\phi_A(k)$ count the number of $1\leq m\leq n_k$ such that the fraction $\frac{m}{n_k}$ does not have denominator $n_j$ for $j<k$ when written in lowest form; equivalently,\[\frac{n_k}{(m,n_k)}\neq n_j\]for all $1\leq j<k$.

Is there a sequence $A$ such that\[\lim_{N\to \infty}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k\leq N}\frac{\phi_A(k)}{n_k}=0?\]



It is trivial that $\phi_A(k)\geq \phi(n_k)$, where $\phi$ is the Euler totient function. Equality is achieved when $A=\mathbb{N}$.

The study of $\phi_A$ was introduced by Cassels \cite{Ca50b}, who proved that there exist sequences such that\[\liminf_{N\to \infty}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{k\leq N}\frac{\phi_A(k)}{n_k}=0.\]Cassels proved that the property of divergence of $\sum_k \frac{f(n_k)}{k}$ implying, for almost all $\alpha$, \[\left\lvert \alpha-\frac{m_k}{n_k}\right\rvert < \frac{f(n_k)}{n_k^2},\]is equivalent to the above $\liminf$ being $>0$.

Erd\H{o}s \cite{Er64b} believed that a sequence with the property in the question does not exist. He could only prove that the limit of $\frac{\phi_A(k)}{n_k}$ as $k\to \infty$ cannot be $0$.

In fact he proved that if $\liminf \frac{\phi_A(k)}{n_k}=0$ then $\limsup \frac{\phi_A(k)}{n_k}=1$. Indeed, the hypothesis implies that for any $\epsilon>0$ there are arbitrarily large $k$ such that $\phi(n_k)<\epsilon n_k$, and hence there are arbitrarily large primes $p$ such that $p$ divides some $n_i\in A$. If $n_k$ is minimal such that $p\mid n_k$ then every $1\leq m\leq n_k$ not divisible by $p$ has the required property, and hence $\phi_A(k)/n_k\geq 1-\frac{1}{p}$.

This was solved by Haight \cite{Ha} who proved that such a sequence does exist (contrary to Erd\H{o}s' expectations).




References


[Ca50b] Cassels, J. W. S., Some metrical theorems in {D}iophantine approximation. {I}. Proc. Cambridge Philos. Soc. (1950), 209--218.

[Er64b] Erd\H{o}s, P., Problems and results on diophantine approximations. Compositio Math. (1964), 52-65.

[Ha] Haight, J. A., Metric Diophantine approximation and related topics. PhD thesis ().
